meanings.definition: Expel (someone) from a property, especially with the support of the law.
meanings.sent1: The landlord had to evict the tenant for not paying rent.
meanings.sent2: The court ordered the landlord to evict the troublesome tenant.
meanings.sent3: The comedy show featured a skit where a landlord tried to evict a clown from a tiny car.
meanings.sent4: In the game of chess, the pawn can evict the opponent's piece from a strategic position.
meanings.sent5: The image of the sheriff evicting the squatters was etched in his memory.

meanings.definition: Remove (someone) from a position or office.
meanings.sent1: The board decided to evict the CEO due to misconduct.
meanings.sent2: The shareholders voted to evict the current board members.
meanings.sent3: The movie plot revolved around a group of rebels trying to evict the corrupt leader.
meanings.sent4: The new technology could evict manual labor from many industries.
meanings.sent5: The coach had to evict the player from the team for violating the rules.

meanings.sent1: The storm's intensity forced the residents to evict their homes.
meanings.sent2: The police had to evict the protesters from the government building.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat managed to evict the dog from its favorite spot on the couch.
meanings.sent4: The strong smell of the chemicals could evict anyone from the laboratory.
meanings.sent5: The loud music from the party next door seemed to evict all thoughts of sleep from her mind.
